required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Improved Intra-operative Safety From Optimal Selection of Anti-slip Surface
clinical_study.official_title: Improved Intra-operative Safety From Optimal Selection of Anti-slip Surface

brief_summary.textblock: To identify the best surface to minimize the risk of intra-operative slipping when placed in Trendelenburg position. The outcomes of interest are to minimize the amount of movement from predefined anatomic landmarks and maximize the ease of performing the intended surgery. The study consists of performing a randomized trial comparing 3 common anti-slip surfaces to determine which surface provides the best result in terms of safety and cost.

detailed_description.textblock: Laparoscopic surgery has become increasingly important in the drive to reduce patient morbidity. The introduction of robotic surgery has only served to accelerate this trend by allowing more complex surgeries to be performed using a minimally invasive technique. A key requirement of any minimally invasive gynecologic procedure is adequate visualization of the pelvis. This necessitates moving the bowel into the upper abdomen which is facilitated by placing patients in the Trendelenburg position. Steep Trendelenburg in the range of 30-40 degrees has historically been referenced as necessary for adequate visualization, but modern studies have found 16-28 degrees to be adequate. In practice, most physicians obtain the maximum Trendelenburg available as increasingly complex surgeries are attempted using minimally invasive techniques.

primary_outcome.measure: Length of displacement when in Trendelenburg
primary_outcome.description: Normal amount of displacement when place in Trendelenburg

secondary_outcome.description: How cost effective is each surface

secondary_outcome.measure: Rank of ease of use by physician
secondary_outcome.description: Surgeon will rate how the surface interferes with surgery
Count of adverse events per surface
Erythema score per surface graded by skin redness
Influence of patient BMI on displacement per anti-slip surface
Influence of patient age on displacement per anti-slip surface
Influence of patient weight on displacement per anti-slip surface
Influence of patient height on displacement per anti-slip surface
Influence of patient hip circumference on displacement per anti-slip surface
Influence of patient waist circumference on displacement per anti-slip surface

arm_group.description: The Pink Pad will be used with subjects undergoing laparoscopic surgery or vaginal surgery while in to Trendelenburg to determine how much slipping is happening during the procedure.
The Bean Bag will be used with subjects undergoing laparoscopic surgery or vaginal surgery while in to Trendelenburg to determine how much slipping is happening during the procedure.
The Gel Pad will be used with subjects undergoing laparoscopic surgery or vaginal surgery while in to Trendelenburg determine how much slipping is happening during the procedure.

intervention.description: Pink Pad made by Xodus Medical Inc. used for patients in steep Trendelenburg position during surgery.
Vac-Pac Bean Bag made by Olympic used for patients in steep Trendelenburg position during surgery.
Gel Pad used for patients in steep Trendelenburg position during surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients scheduled to undergo major laparoscopic or vaginal surgery by participating physicians at University Hospital Cleveland Medical Center
- Patients must not be pregnant
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Patients unable to give consent

facility.name: University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Case Comprehensive Cancer Center
